{{Italic title}} {{Taxobox | name = The Miller | image = Clitopilus prunulus - Lindsey.jpg | image_width = 235px | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | subclassis = [[Hymenomycete]]s | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Entolomataceae]] | genus = ''[[Clitopilus]]'' | species = '''''C. prunulus''''' | binomial = ''Clitopilus prunulus'' | binomial_authority = ([[Giovanni Antonio Scopoli|Scop.]] ex [[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]]) [[Paul Kummer|P. Kumm.]] | synonyms = ''Agaricus prunulus'' Scop., 1772
''Agaricus orcella'' [[Jean Baptiste François Pierre Bulliard|Bull.]], 1793
''Paxillopsis prunulus'' (Scop.) J.E.Lange
''Pleuropus prunulus'' (Scop.) Murrill }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Clitopilus prunulus'' | whichGills = decurrent | capShape = convex | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter=bare | ecologicalType=saprotrophic | sporePrintColor=pink | howEdible=choice }} '''''Clitopilus prunulus''''', commonly known as '''the miller''' or the '''sweetbread mushroom''',{{cite web |url=http://www.mushroomexpert.com/clitopilus_prunulus.html |title=''Clitopilus prunulus'' (MushroomExpert.Com) |work= |accessdate=2009-01-20}} is an edible pink-spored basidiomycete mushroom found in grasslands in Europe and North America. Growing solitary to gregarious in open areas of conifer/hardwood forests; common under Bishop pine (''[[Pinus muricata]]'') along the coast north of San Francisco; fruiting shortly after the fall rains. It has a grey to white cap and decurrent gills. ==Taxonomy== [[County of Tyrol|Tyrolean]] naturalist [[Giovanni Antonio Scopoli]] described the miller as ''Agaricus prunulus'' in 1772.{{cite book | vauthors=Scopoli GA | title= Flora carniolica | edition= Edn 2 | volume= 2| page= 437 | year=1772 | url=http://bibdigital.rjb.csic.es/ing/Libro.php?Libro=983&Pagina=471 | publisher=Impensis Ioannis Pauli Krauss, bibliopolae vindobonensis}} French mycologist [[Jean Baptiste François Pierre Bulliard|Pierre Bulliard]] called it ''Agaricus orcella'' in 1793. German botanist [[Paul Kummer]] erected the genus ''[[Clitopilus]]'' and gave the miller its current name in 1871. ''C. prunulus'' is the [[type species]] of the genus, the limits of which have been redefined more than once.{{cite journal|vauthors=Kluting K, Bergemann S, Baroni TJ|title=Toward a stable classification of genera within the Entolomataceae: A phylogenetic re-evaluation of the Rhodocybe-Clitopilus clade|journal=Mycologia|date=2014|volume=106|issue=6|pages=1127–42|doi=10.3852/13-270|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/263704444_Toward_a_stable_classification_of_genera_within_the_Entolomataceae_A_phylogenetic_re-evaluation_of_the_Rhodocybe-Clitopilus_clade}} Its common names—the miller, and sweetbread mushroom—are derived from its distinctive smell. ==Description== The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is initially convex when young, but in maturity flattens out, usually with a shallow central depression. It is white or light gray or yellow, sticky when moist, and {{convert|3|to|10|cm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} in diameter with a characteristic feel to the touch of [[chamois skin]]. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are [[decurrent]] in attachment to the stipe, spaced together rather closely, and whitish, although they often develop a pinkish hue in age. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is {{convert|3|to|8|cm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} long × 4–15 mm thick, and white. This mushroom has a mealy odor, somewhat like cucumber.Wood WF, Brandes ML, Watson RL, Jones RL, Largent DL. (1994). ''trans''-2-Nonenal, the cucumber odor of mushrooms. ''[[Mycologia]]'' '''86'''(4): 561–563. The [[spore print]] is pink. Spores are 9–12 × 5–6.5 [[micrometre|µm]].{{cite book |author1=Rosanne A. Healy |author2=Huffman, Donald R. |author3=Lois H. Tiffany |author4=George Knaphaus |title=Mushrooms and Other Fungi of the Midcontinental United States (Bur Oak Guide) |publisher=University of Iowa Press |location=Iowa City |year=2008 |page=75 |isbn=1-58729-627-6}} Scopoli described it smelling like freshly ground flour. ''C. prunulus'' may be found growing on the ground in hardwood and coniferous woods in the summer and fall. The variant ''C. prunulus'' var. ''orcellus'' has a slimy cap and white colors. ==Distribution and habitat== ''C. prunulus'' has been recorded from [[Varsey Rhododendron Sanctuary]] in [[Sikkim]],{{cite journal | title=Diversity and conservation of wild mushrooms in Sikkim with special reference to Barsey Rhododendron Sanctuary | vauthors = Das K | date=2010 | journal = NeBIO | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | pages=1–13 | url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Kanad_Das3/publication/264886696_Diversity_and_conservation_of_wild_mushrooms_in_Sikkim_with_special_reference_to_Barsey_Rhododendron_Sanctuary/links/54ec4d6c0cf28f3e65326bd4.pdf }} and from under [[Quercus suber|cork oak]] in Morocco.{{cite journal|vauthors=Yakhlef SB, Kerdouh B, Mousain D, Ducousso M, Duponnois R, Abourouh M|title=Phylogenetic diversity of Moroccan cork oak woodlands fungi|journal=Biotechnol. Agron. Soc. Environ.|date=2009|volume=13|issue=4|pages=521-28|url=http://www.pressesagro.be/base/index.php/base/article/viewFile/419/406}} It is found in [[Valdaysky National Park]] in Russia. A specimen identified as ''C.'' cf ''prunulus'' collected from Kermandie Track in southern Tasmania was related though basal to other collections of the species. ==Volatile compounds== The cucumber odor of this species has been attributed to ''trans''-2-nonenal, which is present at a concentration of 17 [[microgram|µg]] per gram of crushed tissue. ''C. prunulus'' contains the [[volatility (chemistry)|volatile]] compound [[1-Octen-3-ol|1-octen-3-ol]], making it unpalatable to the coastal Pacific Northwest banana slug, ''[[Ariolimax columbianus]]''.Wood WF, Archer CL, Largent DL. (2001). 1-Octen-3-ol, a banana slug antifeedant from mushrooms. ''Biochemical Systematics and Ecology'' '''29'''(5): 531–533. ==Similar-looking species== The poisonous ''[[Clitocybe rivulosa]]'' (fool's funnel) looks similar. The miller has pink spores whereas those of the fools funnel are white, the gills of the miller are more easily pulled away, and the miller smells of raw pastry. The miller also prefers woodland whereas fool's funnel is a grassland species.{{cite book |author=John Wright|title=River Cottage Handbook No.1 Mushrooms |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing PLC|location=London |year=2007|isbn=978-0-7475-8932-7}} ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite book |title=Der Führer in die Pilzkunde |edition=1 |author=Kummer, Paul|authorlink=Paul Kummer |year=1871 |location=Zerbst, Germany |publisher=Luppe |page=97|language=de|url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/34209666}} }} ==External links== {{commons category}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q856834}} [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1772]]
